法規內容.條文內容: The present Regulations are prescribed pursuant to Article 61-1 of the Law of Ships.

The term "passenger ship" when used herein shall mean the ship carrying more than twelve passengers on board, except the 
small ships having been issued passenger ship certificates, to which the regulations herein shall not apply.

The term "passenger" when used herein shall mean every person other than:
1. the master, pilot and the persons employed by shipowners on board a ship on the business of that ship under the command 
of the master;
2. the persons suffering distress, whom the masters are obligated to rescue;
3. the persons on board a ship by way of unlawful means, whom the master or owner of the ship is unable to prevent from or 
stop; and
4. the persons who are unable to leave ships after performing their official duties due to some extraordinary incidents.

Children  less  than one year of age shall not be counted in the prescribed number of passengers.
Ages of children mentioned in the previous paragraph shall be computed based on the actual, full ages upon the time when they go on board and are evidenced by legal documents.

The term "international passenger ship" when used herein shall mean the Republic of China (R.O.C.)-flagged passenger ships, 
navigating in international routes or shorter international routes.

The term "international route" when used herein shall mean the route, other than the shorter international route, in which a ship 
navigates between the ports of the R.O.C. and foreign ports, or between foreign ports.

The term "shorter international route" when used herein shall mean an international route in the course of which a ship is not 
more than 200 nautical miles distance from a port or place where passengers and crew could be placed in safety.  Meanwhile, 
neither the distance between the last port of call in the R.O.C in which the route begins and the final port of destination in a 
foreign country nor the return route shall exceed 600 nautical miles.

The term "domestic passenger ship" when used herein shall mean the R.O.C. flagged passenger ships navigating in the outer 
sea, coastal, inland water or shorter inland water routes.

The term "outer sea route" when used herein shall mean the route in outer seas or between possession islands of the R.O.C, 
which is not the coastal route.

The term "coastal route" when used herein shall mean the route along the sea coast or between possession islands of the 
R.O.C, which is less than 30 nautical miles distant from the coast.

The term "inland route" when used herein shall mean the route in a river, lake and other inland waters or port area of the 
R.O.C. other than the shorter inland water route.

The term "shorter inland water route" when used herein shall mean the approved inland water route in which the route from the 
port of departure to the final port of destination does not exceed 100 nautical miles.

If a coastal route in which a passenger ship navigates should not have severe sea conditions due to natural shields, the owner of 
the ship may apply to the shipping administration authority for determining such route as an inland water route.

The term "ferryboat" when used herein shall mean passenger ships that shuttle regularly between certain domestic ports or 
ferries to link the land transportation, with regular schedules everyday or every other day.

The term "voyages" when used herein shall mean the voyages in which ships sail from the first port of departure to the final 
port of destination.

The term "passenger cabin " when used herein shall mean the cabins, steerage cabins, lobbies, halls, public lounge, medical 
rooms, hospitals, water-closets, toilets and service places, together with passages, corridors and stairways, used exclusively for 
passengers.

The term "cabin" when used herein shall mean the cabins with not more than twelve fixed births provided for accommodations 
of passengers.

The term "steerage cabin" when used herein shall mean the cabins with more than twelve fixed births or ground berths, 
movable berths, reclining chairs, sitting chairs and benches or open cabins used exclusively for passengers.

The term "cabin passenger" when used herein shall mean the passengers who hold cabin passenger tickets and use passenger 
cabins.
The term "steerage passenger" when used herein shall mean the passengers who hold steerage passenger tickets and use 
steerage cabins.
The term "deck passenger" when used herein shall mean the passengers who are carried on tween decks or weather decks 
without designated seats or sleeping places.

The term "passenger deck" when used herein shall mean every tier or every part of the decks above the lowest passenger deck 
used for passengers.

The term "the lowest passenger deck" when used herein shall mean the lowest deck below the summer load line used for 
passengers.
Any non-power-driven passenger ship shall not be operated beyond inland waters.

If the shipping administration authority is in fear for the severe sea conditions in some coastal routes or in certain seasons, it 
may prohibit the passenger ships navigating in such routes to carry passengers on weather decks in such routes or during such 
seasons.

In no case shall any passenger ship be allowed to carry passengers on weather decks when the ship navigates in any outer sea 
route unless approved by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).

法規內容.編章節: Chapter 2  Inspection of Passenger Ships and Pre-sailing Inspections

法規內容.條文內容:
Passenger ships shall be inspected in accordance with the provisions prescribed herein, in addition to the regulations for 
inspections of ships for assigning load lines of ships and for equipment of ships, and other relevant laws.

Passenger ships navigating in international route shall also be inspected pursuant to the provisions set forth in the International 
Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea.

The application for the initial inspection of a passenger ships navigating in international routes shall be made to the shipping 
administration authority on the form, together with five copies each of the following documents: 
1. Principal specifications of the ship;
2. Business plan;
3. Main drawings and calculations; and
4. Other information and drawings the shipping administration authority deems necessary.

The application form shall be the format specified in Schedule 1 annexed hereto.

The principal specifications of ships shall enumerate:
1. General information:
(1) Principal dimensions; 
(2) Speed of ships;
(3) Capacity and deadweight;
(4) Construction standards;
(5) Number of passengers of every class and the allotment thereof;
(6) Number of crew and the allotment thereof; and 
(7) Stability.
2. Hull:
(1) Description of materials used,
(2) Description of subdivision,
(3) Description of fire zone and the constructions thereof,
(4) Description of side scuttles, watertight doors, fire doors, drain ports and all sewage and other discharge holes and 
mechanical gears and the remote control systems thereof on the shell plates below the boundary lines,
(5) Descriptions of passenger decks, and
(6) Passenger cabin and sanitary facilities. 
3. Machinery:
(1) Outline of main engines,
(2) Outline of boilers and the pressure vessels thereof,
(3) Outline of generators, and
(4) Outline of water pumps.
4. Equipment:
(1) Category of equipment and accessories,
(2) Outline of fire prevention, detection, extinguishing and fire alarm      
device, and
(3) Outline of fire fighting equipment.

Except as otherwise specified in laws and regulations, the business plan shall enumerate: 
1. Outline of planned routes,
2. Outline of planned passenger-carrying ports and calling ports,
3. Planned business periods and the number of passengers carried in each period, and
4. Cargo-carrying plan if cargoes are to be carried concurrently.

Principal drawings and calculations shall include:
1. General information:
(1) General arrangement,
(2) Longitudinal sections of interior and exterior of the hull,
(3) Lines,
(4) Hydrostatic curve,
(5) Floodable length curve,
(6) Stability curve,
(7) Intact and damaged stability calculations,
(8) Volumes and horizontal/vertical centers of gravities of cargo holds, oil tanks and ballast tanks,
(9) Detailed layouts of gangways, ventilation, lighting, medical and sanitary facilities of passenger and crew cabins, and 
(10) Capacity and layout of lifeboats, life rafts and davits.
2. Hull:
(1) Midship section,
(2) Longitudinal section,
(3) Shell expansion and framing plan,
(4) Construction of bow, stern and rudder, 
(5) Construction of all decks,
(6) Drawings of pillars and longitudinal girders,
(7) Drawings of watertight and oil-tight bulkheads,
(8) Drawings of main engine and boiler seats,
(9) Drawings of doors, windows and side scuttles,
(10) Drawings of hatch covers and cover plates of watertight decks,
(11) Drawings of watertight doors and control gears, and
(12) Drawing of drain holes on shell plates.
3. Engines and machines:
  (1) General arrangement of engine room,
  (2) Layouts of main and auxiliary boilers and pressure vessels,
  (3) Layout and capacity of bilge pumps,
  (4) Layout of water feed piping,
  (5) Layout of bilge piping,
  (6) Layout of ballast water piping,
  (7) Layout of drainage fittings below bulkhead decks,
  (8) Layout of ventilation,
  (9) Layout and capacity of main generators and emergency generators,
  (10) Electric power switch circuits, and 
  (11) Drawings of lighting fixtures and other electric systems of all decks. 
  4. Fire control:
  (1) Fire zones and the construction thereof,
  (2) List of fire control systems,
  (3) List of fire alarm systems, 
  (4) List of fire detection systems, and 
  (5) List of fire extinguishing systems.

In case of unavailability of all drawings and specifications specified in the three preceding articles, the shipowner may elaborate 
reasons in writing to apply for exemption from the submission of the drawings and specifications.

If the shipowner has furnished the drawings and specifications mentioned above to the same shipping administration authority 
pursuant to other relevant laws and regulations, such drawings and specifications may be exempted from submission or the 
number of copies may be reduced.

In case an existing ship is converted to a passenger ship, or a passenger ships undergoes a substantial modification, the 
drawings and specifications of modification thereof shall be furnished, together with other drawings and specifications that the 
shipping administration authority may deem necessary.

Before the shipping administration authority approves the certified number of passengers, it shall inspect the passenger cabins, 
and exclude those that are not in compliance with the present Regulations from use as passenger cabins.

Before the shipping administration authority issues regular or provisional passenger ship certificates, it shall inspect the 
lighting, ventilation, sanitary, escape and protection facilities before conducting the inspection according to the drawings and 
specifications as specified in Article 28 or 30 herein. If drinking water and meals are supplied, the facilities thereof shall also be 
inspected.

In case of any alteration of the facilities mentioned in the preceding article, the shipowner shall report to the shipping 
administration authority for inspection. If the authority deems, after inspection, that it is necessary to change the certified 
number of passengers or some entries of the passenger ship certificate, it may so approve and renew such certificate.

An application for passenger ship inspection shall be made to the shipping administration authority before the valid period of 
the passenger ship certificate expires.

For a ship navigating in the outer sea or coastal route up to 1,000 nautical miles or more than five days, the shipping 
administration authority at the port the route begins shall send the inspector to verify Item 1 through 7, the first paragraph of the 
preceding article. The ship may be allowed to depart only after inspected and verified.

If the ship mentioned above carries or discharges passengers at some other port of calling in the course of route, the shipping 
administration authority at such port shall inspect and verify Item 5, the first paragraph of the preceding article. While, if the 
ship loads or discharges cargoes, she shall be subject to the inspection and verification of Item 6 and 7, the first paragraph of 
the preceding article.

For a passenger ship navigating in the outer sea or coastal route less than 1,000 nautical miles or five days, or navigating in the 
inland or shorter inland water route, the shipping administration authority at the port the route begins shall send the inspector 
onboard to make spot inspection on Item 1 through 7, the first paragraph, Article 35 herein, at least once in a period not 
exceeding four months.

Before every departure of the ship mentioned above from the port the route begins or some other port in the course of a route, 
with carriage or discharge of passengers or cargoes, the shipping administration authority at such port shall inspect and verify 
Item 5 or 6 and 7, the first paragraph, Article 35, respectively.

A ferryboat or a passenger ship navigating in the shorter inland water route, or a passenger ship that is exempted by the 
shipping administration authority from using the "non-bearer passenger tickets", may be exempted from providing the 
passenger list. However, the master of the ship shall report the number of passengers when the authority checks such number.

When a passenger ship calls at a port, where none of shipping administration authority is established, to carry or discharge 
passengers or cargoes, the local government shall, before departure, inspect and verify the requirements set forth in Item 5 or 
Item 6 and 7, the first paragraph, Article 35, respectively.

When a shipping administration authority deems necessary upon inspecting the requirements set forth in Article 35 through 37, 
it may require conducting tests or drills on some equipment or facilities in order to be aware of the conditions thereof. The 
owner or master of the ship shall not reject such request.

When the shipping administration authority deems that the results of inspection are not in compliance with the requirements, or 
finds that the certified number of passengers exceeds as specified, it shall order to take corrective actions for improvement. 
Any violation of laws or regulations when found during inspection shall be subject to punishment pursuant to such relevant 
laws and regulations.

When the shipping administration authority approves the inspection, the inspector and the master shall endorse two copies of 
report to that effect, with one copy each kept by the authority and the master.
The rates and charges specified in the ship inspection tariff shall be levied and collected for the inspections of passenger ships.

After a passenger ship is completely constructed, she shall receive the inclining experiment under the supervision of shipping 
administration authority. The information data relating to the results of the experiment and the calculations of stability shall be 
submitted for examination and approval by the shipping administration authority.

The information of stability approved by the shipping administration authority mentioned in the preceding article shall be kept 
onboard the ship accessible to the master, enabling him to be precisely aware of different kinds of stability required for 
different loadings.

In case any modification of a passenger ship that may substantially affect the information of stability handed over to the master, 
the revised information shall be sent to the shipping administration authority for approval. If necessary, the ship shall receive 
the inclining experiment once again.

If a passenger ship's basic stability information are obtained from other same type ship's inclining experiment results that have 
been confirmed by the shipping administration authority to be reliably applicable to the ship, she may be exempted from the 
inclining experiment pursuant to Article 44 according to the application of the shipowner.

The intact stability of a passenger ship shall be computed respectively according to the weather condition in the navigation area 
and the carriage of passenger and considering the free surface effect of normally, non-fully filled liquid tank under any normal 
carriage condition. The standard shall be one of the net metacentric heights as specified in the two preceding articles; whichever 
is the greater.

The stability of a damaged passenger ship shall comply with the provisions for the subdivision of passenger ship set forth in 
relevant laws and regulations.

The provisions set forth in Article 48 to 50 are applicable to the power-driven passenger ship of normal proportion and type. In 
case of the ship of special proportion and type, to which these provisions do not apply, the calculations of its stability shall be 
otherwise submitted to the shipping administration authority for approval.

The ballast for a passenger ship with a length of less than 24 meters needed to comply with the stability specification shall be 
the permanent ballast.

Any passenger ship shall establish passenger cabins in accordance with the provisions prescribed in this chapter, except:
1. The passenger ship, which navigates in coastal, inland water or shorter inland water route, of which the route does not 
exceed three hours; or 
2. The passenger ship, which is approved by MOTC to carry passengers on weather decks.

Passenger cabins shall be isolated from the crew accommodations. If it is impossible on account of the tonnage, type, 
construction or intended use of the ship, both cabins shall be clearly divided or restricted as much as possible.

Each space of the passenger cabin shall be marked with the use, class and number in front of the door. Markings shall be made 
in characters or signs if cabins are separated for men and women use respectively.

The floor decks of passenger cabins shall not be placed onto movable beams; they must have proper strength. If they are wood 
decks, they shall be firmly secured and the seams thereof shall be caulked; while, if steel decks, they shall be covered with 
wood boards or other materials that are approved by shipping administration authority.

The steel weather open decks above passenger cabins and steel weather such decks carrying passengers shall be covered in 
accordance with the requirement set forth in the previous paragraph; however, the shipping administration authority may give 
an allowance for the ship that carry deck passengers.

All passenger cabins of any passenger ship shall be installed with stairways and vertical stairways for passengers to promptly 
escape to the lifeboat deck in accordance with the following provisions:
1. Each watertight compartment or similarly restricted space or group of spaces located below the bulkhead deck shall be 
equipped with two escape routes of which at least one shall not go through the watertight door. However, one of the escape 
routes may be exempted if the shipping administration authority approves according to the characteristics and locations of 
compartments, and the number of passengers.  
2. Each main vertical zone or similarly restricted space or group of spaces located above the bulkhead deck shall have at least 
two practical escape routes, of which at least one shall be able to access a stairway forming a vertical escape.
3. The escape routes prescribed in the two preceding paragraphs shall have at least one enclosed stairway readily accessible, 
which shall have as much as possible continuous fire shelter from the level of its origin to the lifeboat embarkation deck. The 
width, number, and continuity of each stairway shall be approved by the shipping administration authority.

There shall be entrances provided for passenger cabins in compliance with the requirements shown below. More than two 
entrances shall be established if the certified number of passengers exceeds 50 passengers. Except as otherwise approved by 
shipping administration authority, there shall keep as much as possible a suitable space between the entrances.
1. Total width of each entrance shall be computed based on the certified number of passengers and 1cm for one person. 
However, every entrance shall be at least 60cm wide; and 
2. Every entrance shall not be directly intruded by rains or waves.

If there are emergency exits in passenger cabins that are in compliance with the following requirements, they may be deemed 
and counted as specified in the preceding article: 
1. The width reaches 60cm;
2. It is easily opened or closed from both sides by one person; and 
3. The signs of the location are easily identifiable for cabin passengers.

If the entrances prescribed in the two preceding articles are far high from the passenger cabin floors, the stairways accessing 
such entrances shall be provided in compliance with the following requirements:
1. The width of the stairways shall be greater than that of the entrances. However, in case of winding stairs or other difficult 
stairs or the upper or lower stairs near which there are obstructions, the shipping administration authority may grant a width 
slightly narrower than that of the entrances;
2. The entrance shall be established in fore and after directions of the ship as much as possible;
3. The angle between the entrance and the floor deck shall be within 45 degrees; and 
4. There shall be handrails on stairs, with fender boards at back.

The shipping administration authority may slightly loosen the requirements of Item 3 and 4 in the previous paragraph for the 
stairs in the emergency exits.

The locations of the passages in steerage cabins accessible to entrances shall be subject to approval of shipping administration 
authority, and the width thereof shall comply with the following requirements:
1. The passage of 4.5m and over in length shall have a width of at least 75cm; and
2. The passage of less than 4.5m in length shall have a width of at least 60cm.
The steerage cabins of less than 15 m2 or having only standee space may be exempted from establishing the passages in 
accordance with the requirements set out in the previous paragraph.

The entrances of the places such as the ship light rooms, paint rooms and combustible oil storerooms shall not connect with the 
passenger cabin doors, or established at the places where may endanger the safety of passengers.

When passenger cabins are adjacent to cargo holds, coal holds, storerooms, ship light rooms, paint rooms and combustible oil 
storerooms, they shall be isolated with steel airtight bulkheads and steel decks.

Passenger cabins shall not adjoin oil tanks, except those in compliance with the following requirements:
1. The passenger cabins, which are additionally installed with a steel airtight bulkhead; and, besides the well ventilation, the 
space between the two bulkheads is accessible; and
2. There shall no manholes or other openings on the top plate of oil tanks, and the plate shall be laid with non-combustible 
materials of at least 38mm in thickness, and there shall be sufficient ventilation for the passenger cabins.

Passenger cabins shall have sufficient windows for catching lights and ventilation. However the number of windows may be 
reduced if the shipping administration authority deems that the lighting and ventilation facilities are adequate.

The steerage cabins on the upper and lower decks of a passenger ship navigating international or outer sea routes shall be 
installed with ventilation windows in each tier of passenger deck individually. The cross-section of the ventilation window, and 
the inlet and outlet thereof shall be computed based on the certified number of passengers and 16 cm2 for every passenger; the 
cross-section of the ventilator of the steerage cabins located at both sides of the engine room shall be computed on the basis of 
21 cm2 for every passenger.

If the ventilator mentioned above is bent, the cross-section thereof shall be increased by an additional quantum of 5% to 10% 
for every bend according to the bending curvature. If it is a deflected ventilator, the cross-section shall be added with a 6% to 
36% additional quantum to each deflection according to the deflecting curvature.

Notwithstanding the requirements set forth in the two previous paragraphs, the cross-section of the ventilator may be properly 
reduced by the shipping administration authority, provided, that the steerage cabin can be ventilated through the deck head 
openings of the superstructure or the deck house, or there is mechanical ventilation device, or there is redundant space in it, or 
the air can flow between it and other cabins.

The passenger ship navigating in the tropical zone shall have her shell plates around the passenger cabins or the uncovered 
weather decks laid with proper heat-resistant materials as a protection.

The cabins and steerage cabins shall be classified according to the following requirements:
1.Cabins:
(1) Class A cabin shall have no more than two fixed berths in one cabin;
(2) Class B cabin shall have no more than four fixed berths in one cabin; and
(3) Class C cabin shall have no more than twelve fixed berths in one cabin. 
2. Steerage cabins:
(1) Class A steerage cabin shall have fixed or movable berths, or reclining facilities; 
(2) Class B steerage cabin shall have board or matting berths;
(3) Class C steerage cabin shall have seats or benches; and
(4) Class D steerage cabin does not have the seats and sleeping facilities as mentioned above.

If various class facilities mentioned in the previous paragraph are mixed in a steerage cabin without fixed partitions, the lowest 
class facility shall be taken for designating the class of the cabin.

Each cabin passenger shall be provided with a fixed berth. It shall not be substituted with a temporary berth or a sofa, nor an 
additional temporary berth or a sofa placed beside it for passenger to sit or sleep unless approved by the shipping 
administration authority due to special reasons.

The fixed berths in cabins shall be permanently secured in the cabin, and the arrangement and size thereof shall be made in 
accordance with the following requirements:
1. The number of tiers of the berth shall not be more than two;
2. Two berths shall not lean together closely, and shall have a passage of at least 75cm in-between;
3. The top of the lower berth of a double-tier berth shall have a height of no less than 30cm above the floor; the distance 
between the tops of the upper and lower berths, and the overhead space above the top of the upper berth shall be no less than 
76cm.
4. At least one side of every berth shall face a passage accessing to the entrance; and
5. The length and width of the inner edge of a berth in an international passenger ship shall be no less than 182cm and 60cm 
respectively, or, in a domestic passenger ship, no less than 180cm and 56cm respectively.

When a passenger ship is equipped with fixed berths for exclusive use of children, which are smaller than the requirements 
prescribed in the two preceding articles, the following provisions shall be observed:
1. The berths shall be clearly labeled with "Exclusively for children"; and
2. The length and width of the inner edge of the berth for children of less than three years of age shall be no less than 100cm 
and 50cm respectively, or, for children of less than twelve years of age, no less than 110cm and 50cm respectively.
Every berth shall have suitable facilities to avoid passengers being thrown out of the berth due to rolling or pitching of the ship.
Every cabin shall be segregated with compact, firm bulkhead, and shall directly access to public passages.
Every cabin shall be installed with strong door and lock, which shall be able to be opened from both sides of the door.

The certified number of passengers of a passenger ship shall comply with the calculations as specified in Schedule 4 annexed 
hereto; besides, it shall be approved by shipping administration authority according to the equipment, stability, watertight 
compartments, passenger cabins, and capacities of provisions and fresh water.

If the certified number of passengers is computed based on the deck area, the computation shall only include the deck areas that 
are provided for exclusive use.

When computing the area of passenger cabins, the following places shall be excluded:
1. Passages,
2. The areas above hatchways,
3. Hatches and the places within 60cm from the circumference thereof, and
4. Cargo ports and the places within 35cm in front and rear thereof, within a width of 60cm from the circumference of the 
ports.

The shipping administration authority may include the areas mentioned in Item 2 to 4 of the previous paragraph into 
calculations when requested by the owner of a passenger ship navigating inland water and shorter water routes, or making non-
stop routes from the port of departure to the port of destination.

The area of passenger cabins or decks shall be computed as follows:
1. For the well-shaped places: average width * length;
2. For the well-shaped places: take the fore, mid and aft widths; add the sum of the fore and aft widths with 4 times of the mid 
width; therewith, the grand total obtained * length/6; 
3. For the inclined and bending areas in the stern behind the spot having a length (from the stern equals to one half of the 
breadth: 2/3 of the length * the fore breadth of the areas. 
4. The area obtained from the above computation shall deduct the areas that shall not be included as specified in the two 
preceding articles.

The certified number of passengers of an international passenger ship shall be approved pursuant to Schedule 4; besides, the 
promenade of at least 0.46 m2 for each passenger shall be provided. The shipping administration authority may reduce the 
certified number if the area of promenade decks is less than the said area, except for the passenger ship navigating in the shorter 
international route.

The certified number of passengers of a passenger ship navigating in the outer sea route, of which the voyage takes up to 48 
hours and above, shall be approved pursuant to Schedule 4; besides, the promenade of at least 0.18 m2 for each passenger shall 
be provided. The shipping administration authority may reduce the certified number if the area of promenade decks is less than 
the said area, unless there is any special reason.

The certified number of passengers of a passenger ship navigating in the inland water or shorter inland water route only in 
daytime may be properly increased as the shipping administration authority may deem appropriate. However, the minimum 
area occupied exclusively by a passenger shall be no less than 0.21 m2.

If the upper deck or other unenclosed places of a passenger ship are permitted to carry passengers by the shipping 
administration authority, the certified number of deck passengers shall be computed as follows:
1. For a ferryboat, the area of deck occupied by every deck passenger shall be no less than 0.40 m2;
2. For a passenger ship whose voyage takes up to 12 hours and above, the area of deck occupied by every deck passenger shall 
be no less than 1.10 m2; and
3. For a passenger ship whose voyage takes less than 12 hours, the area of deck occupied by every deck passenger shall be no 
less than 0.85 m2.

If the shipping administration authority deems necessary, the weather decks used to carry deck passengers as mentioned in the 
previous paragraph shall be provided with awnings and shelter facilities.

The owner of a passenger ship shall publish the certified number of passengers in every part of the ship approved by the 
shipping administration authority in all conspicuous places.

法規內容.編章節: Chapter 6 Fresh Water; Board and room

法規內容.條文內容:
Any passenger ship shall provide sufficient fresh water for all crew members and passengers to the next port where the fresh 
water are available.

The supply of fresh water for crew members and passengers each day shall be as follows:
1. For crew and cabin passengers: no less than 20 liters; and
2. For steerage passengers: no less than 12 liters.

Besides the provision of fresh water pursuant to the standards mentioned in the preceding article, any seagoing passenger shall 
provide additional drinking water according to the days and the number of personnel of the route, based on the volume of 25 
liters per 100 persons per day.

Besides the provision of water pursuant to the standards mentioned in the two preceding articles, any seagoing passenger ship 
shall provide additional fresh waters in at least three-day volume as the emergency water.

If a passenger ship is equipped with the fresh water generator machine, which is approved by the shipping administration 
authority and is inspected before departure, two-thirds of the capacity of the generator may be excluded from computing the 
required volume of the fresh water in stock. Nevertheless, the ship shall provide the emergency water even though its fresh 
water generator has a greater capacity than as required for all persons on board.

The fresh water exclusively used for drinking shall be stored in tanks or drums, which shall not be made of the materials that 
would cause deterioration of taste or quality of the water; nor shall any coating that would cause deterioration of taste or quality 
of water be used for painting the interior of such tanks or drums.

There shall be boiling equipment provided in a passenger ship that cannot supply clean, drinking water for timely supply of the 
water. The equipment shall have a capacity computed according to the certified number of passenger, distance of voyage, and 
condition of voyage, and shall be subject to the approval of the shipping administration authority.

A passenger ship voyaging up to 24 hours and above shall furnish meals to each passenger. The ship shall be provided with 
fresh foods sufficient for the meals for all persons onboard throughout the route and proper refrigerating and cooking 
equipment.

The provision of meals on board mentioned in the previous paragraph shall be indicated in the passenger tickets.

If a passenger ship furnishes meals in her route of less than 24 hours, the provision of meals shall be indicated in the passenger 
tickets. If no meals are provided in a voyage up to 6 hours and above, the vending stand or commissary shall be established on 
board for passengers' needs.

All cabin passengers on board an international passenger ship whose voyage would take up to three days and above shall take 
meals in the mess room, which shall have a capacity of accommodating not less than a half of total cabin passengers to take 
meals at a time.

The mess room may not be set up for an international passenger ship whose voyage is less than three days, and for steerage 
passengers.

All cabin and steerage passengers on board an international passenger ship whose voyage would take up to seven days and 
above shall take meals in the mess room. The mess room of cabin passengers shall have the same capacity as specified in the 
preceding article, and that for steerage passengers shall have a capacity of accommodating not less than one-third of total 
steerage passengers to take meals at a time.

Except as otherwise stipulated in the two preceding articles, the passenger ship furnishing meals for cabin or steerage 
passengers in the mess room shall provide a mess room capable to accommodate no less than one-third of total passengers on 
board. While, if none of such mess room in the ship, there shall be an adequate passage in front of galleys or pantries 
accessible to passengers, except for the passenger ship navigating shorter voyage, which does not furnish meals.

The berths in passenger cabins of a passenger ship shall be furnished with clean sleeping accommodations such as bed 
blankets, mattresses, coversheets and pillows, as well as proper quantity of clean sleeping accommodations for steerage 
passengers to rent.

An international passenger ship whose voyage would take up to twenty four hours and above shall provide in every cabin at 
least a wash basin, and for steerage passengers, one public wash room for men and women separately. The number of the 
basins shall be calculated based on the certified number of passengers, and at least one for every twenty persons.

A domestic passenger ship whose voyage would take up to twenty four hours and above and of which the certified number of 
passengers is over 100 shall provide public wash room, of which the size shall be subject to the approval of the shipping 
administration authority.

An international passenger ship whose voyage would take up to seventy two hours and above shall provide public bath rooms, 
for men and women separately, with bath-tub or shower facilities, and cold and hot water supply. The number for the bathing 
facilities shall be calculated based on the certified number of passengers, and at least one for every 100 persons and one for the 
residue number. If there are exclusive bathtubs or showers in passenger cabins, the certified number of cabin passengers may 
be excluded from the calculation of the number of bathing facilities.

If a bathroom mentioned in the preceding article is combined with a washroom, there shall be a partition board to separate 
them. All bathtubs and shower spaces shall be of the single type and shall be installed with partition board for individual use.

The shipping administration authority shall properly approve the establishment of bathtub or shower facilities of a domestic 
passenger ship whose voyage would take up to seventy-two hours and above.

An international passenger ship whose voyage would take up to twenty four hours and above shall provide public water 
closets, for men and women separately, with flush toilets of which the number shall be calculated based on the certified 
number of passengers, and at least one for every 25 persons. If there are water closets in cabins, the number of cabin 
passengers may be excluded from the calculation of the number of the flush toilets.

Besides the flush toilet mentioned in the previous paragraph, there shall have some urinals provided for male passengers. The 
flush toilets shall be of single type and separated with partition board for individual use.

A domestic passenger ship whose voyage would take up to twenty hours and above shall provide public water closets, for men 
and women separately. The number of flush toilets shall be calculated based on the certified number of passengers, and at least 
one for every 35 persons. The flush toilets shall be of single type and properly partitioned.

Besides the flush toilet mentioned in the previous paragraph, there shall have some urinals provided for male passengers.

A passenger ship whose voyage would take thirty minutes upward and less than twenty-four hours shall properly provide 
public water closets. If the water closets are for use by both men and women, each flush toilet shall be installed with door latch.

An international passenger ship whose voyage would take up to seventy-two hours and above shall provide exclusive sick 
bays, of which the deck area shall be no less than 3.4 m2. If the certified number of passengers is 15, an additional area of 1.67 
m2 shall be required for every additional 50 persons, with the number of less than 50 to be counted as 50 persons.

The sick bay prescribed in the preceding article shall be built on the top passenger deck and properly segregated off from other 
passenger cabins.

In addition to the sick bay to be built as prescribed above, an international passenger ship whose voyage would take up to seven 
days and above shall establish one isolated sick bay to be used exclusively for the patient who suffers from an epidemic disease 
or heavy sickness. If more than four sick bays are built, two of which shall be used as the isolated sick bays, for men and 
women separately.

There shall be in every such sick bay the supplies of beds, toilet utensils and flush toilets; and a bathroom in every isolated sick 
bay additionally.

An international passenger ship whose voyage would take up to seventy two hours and above shall provide a medical room, 
which shall be supplied with medicine stands, diagnostic beds, and different necessary medical supplies and apparatus.

Any sick bay and medical room shall in no case be used to store other utensils or cargoes.

Except as used exclusively for patient passengers, any sick bay shall in no case be used for any other purpose.

Any medical room shall in no case be used as a bedroom for any person.

Any passenger ship in which a medical room is established shall carry some duly qualified and competent surgeons and 
nurses; the number thereof shall be specified by the shipping administration authority.

A domestic passenger ship whose voyage would take up to seventy-two hours and above shall provide a proper number of 
exclusive sick bays and at least one nurse. A medical room and a qualified surgeon shall be provided additionally if there are 
over three hundred passengers on board; however, the surgeon may be not required if approved by the shipping administration 
authority due to extraordinary circumstances.

Any passenger ship having neither medical rooms nor sick bays shall keep on board the simple and convenient medical 
apparatus and medical supplies for emergency. The number and category thereof shall be prescribed by the medical authority 
after coordination is made between the shipping administration authority and such authority. The apparatus and supplies shall 
be put under the custody of the high-ranking officer designated by the master of the ship.

Passenger tickets are provided in two categories, the non-bearer ticket and bearer ticket. The non-bearer ticket shall be used in 
all passenger ships navigating in the international routes, and the outer sea and coastal routes, while other passenger ships may 
use the bearer ticket.

In every passenger ticket there shall be indicated the owner or carrier of the ship, name of ship, port of departure, port of 
destination, class of cabin, cabin number, fare, ticket number, estimated departure time and issuing date. The valid period shall 
be specified in the bearer ticket.

In every non-bearer ticket there shall be indicated the name, age, sex and domicile of origin of the passenger, as well as the 
name and job title of the person issuing the ticket.

All entries relative to the accident insurance subscribed for passengers traveling in the special route and districts shall be 
indicated.
The owner or carrier shall submit the form or forms of passenger tickets to the shipping administration authority for approval.

If meals are supplied in the ship, the ticket fare shall include the charges for the meals. The expenses for accident insurance 
subscribed to cover the routes in special route and districts shall be so indicated in the tickets.

Children one year and upwards but under three years of age boarding an international passenger ship, and children three years 
and upwards but under twelve years of age boarding a domestic passenger ship shall be provided with exclusive berths, for 
which a half of the adult fare shall be charged.

Children under one year of age boarding an international passenger ship, and children under three years of age boarding a 
domestic passenger ship together with their custodians shall be free from charges. However, every custodian may take one 
such child only, and a quarter of adult fare shall be payable for the other such children; and in case a berth is requested, the 
charge shall be a half of the adult fare for every such child.
Any non-bearer ticket shall in no case be assigned to any other person.

Any passenger who is disabled, heavily sick, imbecile, old or infirm or under six years of age thus shall require to be cared 
may not be allowed to board the ship if he/she is not attended by any person although he/she holds a passenger ticket.

Any passenger who is an epidemic patient and does not comply with relevant regulations governing the carriage of epidemic 
patients shall be rejected to board a ship although he/she holds a passenger ticket.

Any passenger who is drunk or creates chaos shall be rejected to board any ship.

A passenger ship providing meals for passengers shall furnish all meals throughout the voyage from the date of boarding to 
the time the ship arrives at destination and the master announces to disembarkation.

Any passenger who does not have the meals furnished by the ship shall be deemed to waive his/her right, and in no case may 
he/she claim for refund of part of ticket fare.

If a passenger who requests the lower class berth instead, or to change to the higher class from the lower one, and the berth so 
requested is available, the refund or compensation for the difference of ticket fare shall be computed pursuant to the rules the 
carrier specifies.

The carrier may reject the embarkation of any passenger who does not bring with his/her complete traveling documents. If any 
forged or fraudulent document is found resulting in rejection of disembarkation at the destination indicated in the passenger 
ticket, the carrier shall be held responsible for sending such passenger to other port or back to the port of departure. However, 
such passenger shall be held responsible for paying the fare for such transfer or the fare for the return trip.

The refund of ticket fare shall be computed pursuant to the Maritime Law for any passenger to whom one of the following 
incidents occurs:
1. The contract of carriage is terminated;
2. The passenger is unable or refuses to board before the ship departs due to death, sickness or any reason beyond control;
3. The passenger does not board the ship in the designated time before departure or during the voyage, or is forced to leave the 
ship by the master pursuant to his authority; or
4. The passenger disembarks out of his/her own will, or due to sickness or death.

The number of passenger tickets sold for every voyage of a passenger ship shall not exceed the certified number of passengers 
of that ship.

In principle, cabin tickets shall be sold separately to men and women, except for the dependents of a passenger, who may share 
a cabin with the passenger.

Luggage may be brought onboard by passengers or delivered to the carrier for carriage by the ship that the passengers board, 
except the prohibited or unlawful articles.

If there is a fear that the property of an article could damage the ship or endanger human health, the carrier or the master of the 
ship may reject to carry such article, either as the hand luggage or the accompanied luggage.

Except hand luggage, the carrier or master of a passenger ship under 200 gross tonnage or a ferryboat may reject to check any 
luggage.

The carrier shall draw working rules for handling passengers' hand luggage and accompanied luggage, in terms of number of 
pieces, weight, volume limitation free luggage, allowance and rates for excess luggage or other necessary regulations. The rules 
shall be submitted to the shipping administration authority for approval.

The carrier of a passenger ship shall not be held responsible for safekeeping of hand luggage brought on board the ship by 
passengers.
Passengers holding children tickets shall be given a free luggage allowance equivalent to a half of that for adult tickets.

Passengers shall check luggage with passenger tickets, and the carrier or master shall subscribe to issue luggage check upon 
acceptance of such luggage.
The luggage checked by passengers shall be carried on board that the passengers embark.

When checking luggage for carriage, passengers may declare the amount of compensation for damage or loss, if any, and the 
shipowner or carrier may levy and collect additional charge for the value declared.

If the master of a passenger ship has doubt that some hand or accompanied luggage is in violation of the proviso in the first 
paragraph and the second paragraph, Article 137, the master may request passengers to declare in detail the contents thereof. 
He may inspect such luggage in question any time when he thinks necessary.

The inspection of the luggage by the master as mentioned in the previous paragraph shall be made with the presence of the 
passenger concerned, except that there is any reason beyond control.

In case the master finds, during inspecting luggage pursuant to the preceding article, that there have some articles mixed with 
those specified in the proviso in First paragraph, and Second paragraph, Article 137, he shall refuse to carry such articles. If the 
articles are found during navigation, he may destroy or temporarily seal to store such articles depending upon the their 
properties, and shall report the same to the authority concerned for disposal after the ship arrives at the port.

The damage and expenses incurred during the inspection mentioned in the previous paragraph shall be borne by the passenger. 
If no articles relative to the proviso in First paragraph, and Second paragraph, Article 137 are found during inspection, the 
damage or expenses incurred shall be for carrier's account.

The accompanied luggage shall be delivered to passengers at a convenient place in the port of destination, which is designated 
by the carrier. The luggage may also be delivered in a midway port if passengers make the requests in advance, which is 
approved by the master and is recorded in the luggage receipt.

When the accompanied luggage arrives, the carrier shall deliver it against the luggage check pursuant to the preceding article. If 
the passenger does not claim for his/her luggage at the time, he/she shall take it within 48 hours in the place designated by the 
carrier. Charges shall be payable for delay in taking delivery.

If a passenger fails to present the luggage check to claim for his/her luggage, the carrier may only release such luggage against 
the certificate evidencing the right to claim for the luggage, or a proper guarantee.
The carrier shall be responsible for all obligatory behaviors stipulated in the luggage check.

Once the luggage is delivered to the person who is entitled to the delivery, the carrier shall be deemed to have implemented its 
obligation enumerated in the luggage check, except, however, if:
1. The person who is entitled to the luggage had notified in writing the carrier of any damage or loss before or upon taking 
delivery;
2. The person had notified in writing the carrier of the damage or loss that is not apparent within three days after taking 
delivery; or
3. The damage to or loss of the luggage had been recorded in the certificate of delivery.

The right of claim of the person entitled to the luggage for damage shall be exterminated if such right is not executed within one 
year after the day of delivery or the day on which the delivery should be made.

When a passenger ship carries cargoes concurrently, the stability of the ship shall be in compliance with the provisions set forth 
in Chapter 3.

When a passenger ship carries concurrently a large volume of bulk cargoes, the ship shall have the loading plan that is 
approved by the shipping administration authority.

The loading plan shall comprise stowage arrangements and stability computations.

Except that there shall be special equipment and safe, reliable measures, which are approved by the shipping administration 
authority, any passenger ships shall in no case be allowed to carry dangerous cargoes concurrently.

Except that there shall be safe packing and reliable storage facilities for explosives, any passenger ship shall in no case be 
allowed to carry the following explosives:
1. Safety ammunition and safety fuses;
2. A small quantity of explosives not exceeding 9 kgs net in total; 
3. Distress signals used for ships and airplanes, not exceeding 1,016kgs net in total; and
4. Fireworks not easily exploded fiercely.

Item 3 of the previous paragraph does not apply to the passenger ship under 500 gross tons, and Item 4 of the same paragraph 
does not apply to the passenger ship carrying passengers in the steerage cabins or under 500 gross tons.

Except as otherwise approved by shipping administration authority, any passenger ship shall in no case be allowed to carry 
deck cargoes concurrently. The passenger ships that so carry shall comply with the provisions set forth in Article 117, 
Maritime Law.

When granting the approval mentioned in the previous paragraph, the shipping administration authority shall re-compute the 
certified number of passengers by deducting the spaces where the concurrent deck cargoes are stowed.

When livestock and live poultry are carried on a passenger ship, there shall be proper spacing and appropriate facilities for 
feeding and cleaning.
Passengers on board a passenger ship shall obey the command of the master and observe the order of the ship.

Any passenger on board a passenger ship shall not drink excessive wine, gamble or do any unlawful behavior. The master of 
the ship may order to stop such a behavior if it is done willfully. Or, he may enforce obedience to his order against those who 
do not obey and may ask some other passengers to act as the witnesses.

In case of a marriage, birth, death, missing or injury occurring on board a passenger ship, the master shall record the same in 
the logbook and issue a certificate to that effect.
Any restricted area and inaccessible or untouchable equipment shall be clearly labeled.

Any berth of crewmember shall in no case be provided for passenger use unless granted by the master owing to special 
incidents.

Before a passenger ship departs, the master of the ship shall appoint the officers to inspect and check the hull and machinery to 
ensure that they are in normal state, and to have the equipment and accessories thereof readily available. Specific persons shall 
be designated to take up tasks for the emergent case, such as life saving, fire fighting, and rescuing.

Apart from the requirements stipulated in the preceding article, the master shall post up, before the passenger ship departs, the 
muster list in crew compartments.

The muster list mentioned in the preceding article shall include: 
1. All crewmembers' assigned duties and the positions where they shall be when different emergencies happen;
2. Assembling passengers and direct passengers the actions to take and the positions where they shall be; and 
3. Markings and Indications of different emergency sounds and signals.

Each lifeboat shall be controlled by a designated deck officer who is a qualified lifeboat operator, with a designated deputy 
officer assigned. The controller shall keep in his hand the name list of lifeboat crewmembers and shall be responsible for 
familiarizing them with all tasks.

The qualified crew of lifeboat mentioned in the preceding article shall be the persons who are tested and pass the tests, and 
comply with the following requirements with relevant certificates issued to them to that effect:
1. They have received various operational training of recovering and launching lifeboats and other lifesaving equipment, rowing 
and maneuvering the propulsive machinery; 
2. They are familiar with practical operation of lifeboats and other lifesaving equipment; and 
3. They are aware of and able to answer all questions regarding lifesaving equipment.
Every motor lifeboat shall be manned with the person able to manage and operate the machinery therein.
Every lifeboat that carries radio and search light equipment shall be manned with the person able to operate such equipment.

Every life raft shall be manned with the person that is familiar with management and operation of such raft. However, the 
requirement may be relieved for the passenger ship navigating in the shorter international route or coastal and inland water 
routes if approved by the shipping administration authority.

All watertight doors on the bulkheads of compartments of a passenger ship during navigation shall be shut; however, if they 
shall be open due to working need, they shall be able to be shut any time.

A drill of operation of all shutoffs of watertight doors, side scuttles, active live valves and drain ports, soot and garbage chutes 
shall be made at least once a week. However, one full drill shall be conducted on the ship navigating a voyage of up to seven 
days and above before she leaves a port and at least once every seven days thereafter during the voyage.

All power watertight doors and hinged doors located on the main transverse bulkheads shall be operated every day during 
voyage.

All watertight doors and connecting accessories and indicators thereof, and all active valves that shall be shut off as required for 
keeping watertightness and that in the connecting pipes required for damage control, shall be inspected periodically at least once 
every seven days during navigation.
The public address system shall be operated to test at least once every seven days.

Steering gear, steam horn, and communicating systems between the navigation bridge, wheel house and machinery space shall 
be inspected and tested once before departure.

Before a passenger ship leaves sheltered waters, the cargo hatches, manholes and air pipes on weather decks shall be inspected 
and kept closed tightly.
The line-throwing device of a passenger ship, if any, shall be operated to test once every six months.
The emergency lights and the power system thereof of a passenger ship, if any, shall be tested once every seven days.

The master of an international passenger ship shall direct his crew the lifesaving and fire drills once every seven days, and once 
after the ship leaves the last port; except for the ship navigating in a shorter international route.

The master of a domestic passenger ship shall direct his crew the lifesaving and fire drill once every fourteen days.

The master of a passenger ship navigating in the international or outer sea route for a voyage that take fourteen days and above 
shall command every class of crew members to gather and direct passengers to make lifesaving and fire drills within 24 hours 
after the ship leaves the port of departure.

In the drills for lifeboats that are conducted consecutively, each group of lifeboats shall be lifted overboard by turn, and shall be 
lowered down at least once every four months.

The time, place and condition of each of the inspections, tests, operations, drills provided in Article 174 through 183, together 
with any defect found and corrective measures thereof, shall be recorded in the logbook.

Every watertight door, side scuttle, side door, fire door and any other opening that shall be shut during navigation pursuant to 
regulations shall be so shut before the ship leaves a port, and the exact time of opening and closing shall be recorded in the 
logbook.

In a passenger ship there shall be the descriptions of various signals to gather passengers and the responsive actions for 
passengers to take against emergent cases, which shall be elaborated in proper words, figures, tables and lists and posted up in 
the eye-catching place in every passenger cabin.

In a passenger ship there shall be a clearly prepared Damage Control Plan illustrating for each deck and hold the boundaries of 
the watertight compartments, the openings therein with the means of closure and position of any control thereof, and the 
arrangements for the correction of any list due to flooding. The plan shall be posted up permanently in proper places, and the 
manuals elaborating such information shall be also provided for crew's use.

In a passenger ship there shall be a clearly prepared Fire Control Plan illustrating fire control stations, zones, alarms, detection 
system, sprinkler system and extinguishing equipment on decks; the methods accessing different compartments and decks; 
and the ventilation system, including the positions of the control device and switch board of the main fan and Number of each 
fan in compartments. The plan shall be posted up in the places for crew to read.

The plan mentioned in the previous paragraph may be substituted with manuals if approved by the shipping administration 
authority; such manuals shall be distributed to key persons on board the ship, with one copy kept in the places where are 
accessible at all times.

The plans or manuals mentioned in the two preceding articles shall be updated from time to time to ensure that they are of the 
latest editions.

If the owner of a passenger ship or a dry cargo ship desires to carry passengers exceeding the certified number stipulated in the 
passenger ship certificate or exceeding twelve passengers owing to the temporary or seasonal demand, he may apply to the 
shipping administration authority for a provisional passenger ship certificate pursuant to the provisions set forth in this chapter.

When making the application mentioned in the preceding article, the owner of the ship shall submit the passenger-carrying plan 
and necessary drawings and specifications to the shipping administration authority for examination and approval.

Upon receiving the application mentioned in the previous paragraph, the shipping administration authority, apart from verifying 
the temporary number of passengers pursuant to this chapter, shall send the inspector on board to inspect the ship, and
subscribe to issue the provisional passenger ship certificate after approval.

The stability of a temporary passenger ship shall comply with the provisions set forth in Chapter 3. The watertight 
compartments, fire fighting equipment and structural fire protection may be properly relived or exempted if approved by the 
shipping administration authority.

The lifesaving equipment of a temporary passenger ship shall comply with the requirements applicable to the equivalent class 
passenger ship as prescribed in the regulations governing lifesaving equipment of ships.

When a dry cargo ship temporarily carries more than twelve passengers, the capacity of the lifeboats or light boats in both sides 
of the ship may only be computed based on the side that has smaller capacity.

The certified number of passengers of a temporary passenger ship shall be computed according to the standard not lower than 
as stipulated in Schedule 5 annexed hereto.

The spaces between decks of a temporary passenger ship, of which the height is less than 1.52m, shall in no case be used as 
passenger cabins. When computing the certified number of temporary passengers in the spaces under 1.82m high, the deck 
area allotted to each passenger shall be computed according to the area set out in Schedule 5, plus 20%.

The places in a temporary passenger ship, which are provided for passenger use, shall have adequate ventilation and light 
approved by the shipping administration authority according to actual conditions.

Any temporary passenger ship navigating in the outer sea or coastal route shall be provided with sufficient drinking water of no 
less than 10 liters per passenger per day, not counting in the water for cooking.

Any temporary passenger ship shall be equipped with adequate water closets, for men and women separately, of which the 
number of flush toilets shall be provided according to the certified number of temporary passengers, at least one for every 40 
persons. However, such number may be properly decreased for the voyage of less than six hours.

In a temporary passenger ship of which the voyage would take up to 24 hours and above there shall be wash facilities to the 
number that the shipping administration authority shall approve.
Any existing sick bay or medical room in a passenger ship shall in no case be changed to a passenger cabin.

The lower cargo holds, deep tanks and water and oil tanks of a passenger ship shall in no case be changed to temporary 
passenger cabins.

The lowest point of the top deck of any temporary passenger cabin shall not be lower than the max water load line. The 
stairway from the weather deck to the passenger deck shall be solidly constructed to shelter winds and rains. The stairways of a 
passenger ship navigating in the outer sea or coastal route shall be installed with watertight doors that should be able to be 
opened or closed from inside or outside.

Any temporary passenger ship navigating in international routes shall comply with the provisions set forth in relevant 
international conventions.
The provisions set forth in Chapter 4 through 7 do not apply to temporary passenger ships.

Any passenger ship without regular or provisional passenger ship certificate shall in no case carry more than twelve 
passengers, nor shall so carry after the certificate of the ship expires.

When the shipping administration authority approves a passenger ship after inspection or survey and grants her the certified 
number of passenger, the authority shall subscribe to issue the passenger ship certificate to that effect to be effective for not 
exceeding one year.

The passenger ship certificate shall be made on the format as set forth in Schedule 2 annexed hereto.

In case the number of and the classes for passengers carried on board, a passenger ship vary with the regular state of weather in 
certain season in her voyage, the carrier may apply for indicating such variations with seasons and districts in the certificate.

Before making an increase, decrease or modification of the passenger cabin arrangement of a passenger ship but it would affect 
the certified number of passengers or the compliance of the entries of the passenger ship certificate, the owner shall furnish 
revised plans and drawings and specifications to the shipping administration authority for approval. None of works for such 
purpose shall be done unless approval is granted. The passenger ship certificate of the ship shall be renewed after such work is 
inspected and approved.

The application of the owner of a passenger ship for a provisional passenger ship certificate shall be made pursuant to the first 
paragraph, Article 57, the Law of Ships on the application form to the shipping administration authority at the port of calling.

If the shipping administration authority deems necessary, it may notify the applicant of re-submission of business plan and 
relevant drawings and specifications.

Upon receiving the application mentioned in the preceding article, the shipping administration authority shall send its inspector 
on board to inspect the seaworthiness and the compliance of the ship with the regulations set forth herein. The shipping 
administration authority shall subscribe to issue a provisional passenger ship certificate to the effect that it approves the 
inspection and calculates the certified number of passengers. The certificate shall be valid for a period not exceeding two 
months.

The provisional passenger ship certificate shall be made on the format as specified in Schedule 3 annexed hereto.

When the owner of a passenger ship applies for a provisional passenger ship certificate pursuant to the second paragraph, 條
號：57, the Law of Ships, he shall make the application by furnishing the reports issued by a classification societyrecognized 
by MOTC in respect of the ship's seaworthiness and the number of passengers the ship may carry on board to the R.O.C. 
embassy or consulate, representative office, liaison office, or Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) authorized organization at 
or near the port of calling.

The provisional passenger ship certificate issued by a R.O.C. embassy or consulate, representative office, liaison office or 
MOFA authorized organization shall be valid for a period not exceeding two months, and it shall be made on the format as 
specified in Schedule 3-1 annexed hereto.

The owner of a passenger ship who acquires a provisional passenger ship certificate pursuant to the preceding article shall 
apply to the shipping administration authority for issuing a regular passenger ship certificate upon expiration of the provisional 
certificate, which shall then be surrendered for cancellation.

Before a passenger ship certificate expires or any entry thereof is altered, the shipowner shall apply in writing for renewing the 
certificate. If the business plan of the ship is changed, the revised plan and necessary drawings and specifications shall be 
attached to the application.

If the passenger ship certificate of an international passenger ship expires during navigation abroad, the shipowner shall apply 
in writing attached with the certificate of sea worthiness issued by the classification society recognized by MOTC to the R.O.C. 
embassy or consulate, representative office, liaison office or MOFA authorized organization at or near the port of calling for 
issuing a certificate for returning via the approved route.

When the shipping administration authority or the R.O.C. embassy or consulate, representative office, liaison office or MOFA 
authorized organization issues the regular or provisional passenger ship certificate, it shall issue a passenger ship safety 
certificate covering a period the same as granted to such passenger ship certificate.

The passenger ship safety certificate shall be made on the format as specified in Schedule 6 and 7 annexed hereto.

The regular or provisional passenger ship certificate, the passenger ship safety certificate and the layout of deck passengers 
shall be posted up in the conspicuous apparent places in the ship.

The master of a foreign flag passenger ship carrying more than twelve passengers and departing from a ROC international port 
shall submit valid passenger- carrying permit for inspection by the shipping administration authority at the port. The ship shall 
not be allowed to carry more than twelve passengers unless the certificate is verified and approved.

A certificate fee of NT$300 shall be levied and collected for each application for issuing, renewing, reissuing a regular or 
provisional passenger ship certificate and passenger ship safety certificate.
The present Regulations shall come into force on the day of promulgation.
